nodes.name: JavaScript
nodes.data: JavaScript was created at Netscape by Brendan Eich. Netscape submitted JavaScript to Ecma International for standardization in 1996. It was officially standardized in the ECMAScript language specification in 1997, and is currently at version 5.1 as specified in ECMA-262, which was released in June 2011. JavaScript is trademarked by the Oracle Corporation.

nodes.name: HTML
nodes.data: Created by Tim Berners-Lee in approximately 1990, HTML was heavily influenced by the ISO-standardized SGML. HTML was originally submitted to IETF for standardization in 1993. The IETF later created an HTML Working Group, which published HTML 2.0 in 1995. The W3C took over maintaining the specification in 1996 due to internal IETF politics, and the IETF HTML Working Group was dissolved. The most recent version is HTML 4.01, standardized in 2008 by ISO/IEC JTC1/SC34. The W3C published an official recommendation for HTML5 in October 2014.

nodes.name: CSS
nodes.data: Originally proposed by Håkon Wium Lie in 1994, the first W3C recommendation for CSS1 was co-authored by Bert Bos and released by the HTML Editorial Review Board in 1996. The W3C formed the CSS Working Group in 1997, which created CSS2 later that year and published it as a W3C recommendation in 1998. Rather than work on a single specification for CSS3, the working group has divided it into more than 50 modules in varying stages of version stability and draft status. As of April 2015, seven of these modules have been published as formal W3C recommendations.

nodes.name: DOM
nodes.data: The Document Object Model is a language-independent convention for representing and interacting with objects in HTML, XHTML, and XML documents. DOM Level 0, called Legacy DOM, was introduced with JavaScript in 1995. Intermediate versions of DOM were released throughout the browser wars of the 1990s, though none of these versions were standardized. The W3C recommended DOM Level 1 for standardization in 1998. DOM Level 3, published in 2004, is the current release of the specification. DOM Level 4 is under development. Work on DOM is handled by several W3C working groups, particularly the HTML, SVG, and the Web Applications Working Groups.

nodes.name: SVG
nodes.data: Scalable Vector Graphics is an XML-based image format that supports interactivity and animation, and was initially developed by the W3C's SVG Working Group in 1998. SVG 1.0 became a W3C recommendation in 2001. After SVG 1.0, the specification was modularized to allow further work on specific feature sets. The latest release is SVG 1.1 Second Edition, published in 2011. SVG 2.0 is in Working Draft stage as of August, 2012.

nodes.name: MathML
nodes.data: Mathematical Markup Language is an application of XML for describing mathematical and scientific content on the web. MathML 1.0 was the first standard released as a W3C recommendation in 1998. The latest release is MathML 3.0, which was published as a W3C recommendation on April 10, 2014. Work on the specification is handled by the W3C’s Math Working Group. Competing standards include OpenMath and the ISO/IEC JTC1 standard Office Open XML.

nodes.name: HTTP
nodes.data: Hypertext Transfer Protocol is an application protocol for distributing hypermedia. Tim Berners-Lee is largely credited with the invention of HTTP along with the World Wide Web sometime around 1989. Official standards development for HTTP has largely happened within the IETF, though the W3C also liaises with the IEFT HTTP Working Group. HTTP/1.1 is the most commonly used version and has been updated and specified in a series of IETF RFCs. The latest version is HTTP/2, which was approved for publication as an IETF standard in February 2015.

nodes.name: JSON
nodes.data: JSON, also called JavaScript Object Notation, is a language-independent data format originally specified by Douglas Crockford sometime around 2001. It is specified in two competing official standards, IETF RFC 7159 (published March 2014) and Ecma International ECMA-404 (published October 2013).

nodes.name: TCP/IP
nodes.data: TCP/IP, also called the Internet Protocol suite, is a model and set of communications protocols used for computer networks. It was developed in the late 1960s by Robert Kahn and Vint Cerf through research funding from DARPA, an agency of the US Department of Defense. TCP/IP became a standard protocol after a lengthy industry battle over other protocols in the 90s, which included a specification from ISO agency Open Systems Interconnection. The Internet Protocol Suite is currently at IPv4 and is maintained through the IETF and its sibling committee, IRTF. IPv6, is currently in development.

nodes.name: Web APIs
nodes.data: Web APIs are a collection of different JavaScript APIs developed and openly specified across several different working groups. They include such technologies as WebRTC, Web Audio, Web Workers, Web Sockets, Geolocation, Storage, and File System to name a few. Much of the specification work for these technologies takes place in the Web Applications Working Group, HTML Working Group, and W3C TAG.

nodes.name: Ecma International
nodes.data: The European Computer Manufacturers Association was founded in 1961 with a goal to standardize computer systems in Europe. The name was changed to Ecma International in 1994, and today Ecma is a private, non-profit standards organization working on standardizing information communication technology and consumer electronics. It is comprised of four primary units: a General Assembly, a basic Management structure, a Secretariat, and a Co-ordinating Committee. The standards work itself is done within technical committees, which are formed by the Secretariat and comprised of Ecma members. Ecma has 69 listed members, most of which are non-voting, non-profit members.

nodes.name: WHATWG
nodes.data: The Web Hypertext Application Working Group was founded in 2004 by individuals from Apple, Mozilla Foundation, and Opera Software. It describes itself as a “growing community of people interested in evolving the Web,“ which anyone can contribute to by joining the WHATWG mailing list. WHATWG editors maintain several specifications, including specs for HTML, DOM, and JavaScript which it describes as ‘living standards' that are continuously updated. In 2007, the W3C HTML Working Group agreed to use WHATWG's HTML5 specification as the starting point for its work on the next W3C HTML specification.

nodes.name: W3C
nodes.data: The World Wide Web Consortium was founded in 1994 by Tim Berners-Lee. It is the primary standards body for several web technologies including HTML, CSS, MathML, and XML. Specification development is handled through a variety of W3C working groups. The consortium is administered jointly by university groups MIT/CSAIL, Keio University, Beihang University, and ERCIM, and a staff of about 80 people including an executive and business development team. The W3C is governed by nearly 400 dues-paying members, who represent businesses, nonprofit organizations, universities, government entities, and individuals.

nodes.name: ISO
nodes.data: The International Organization for Standardization is a network of national standards bodies with three membership categories: Member bodies, the only members of ISO with voting rights; Correspondent members, who are informed of ISO's work but do not participate in standards-setting; and Subscriber members, which represent countries with smaller economies and pay a reduced fee. Membership is distributed between two assembly groups: the Council, which provides guidance, governance, and budget-setting; and the Technical Management Board, which oversees technical committees who develop and maintain more than 19,500 ISO standards. ISO is coordinated by a Central Secretariat in Geneva.

nodes.name: IEC
nodes.data: The International Electrotechnical Commission is a non-profit organization working on standards for all electrical, electronic, and related technologies. There are 82 member countries, called National Committees, which represent their nation's electrotechnical interests. Another 82 countries are recognized as Affiliates—developing nations becoming more involved in IEC standards work. It is comprised of a Council of National Committees, a Council Board which oversees an Executive Committee, Standardization Management Board, Market Strategy Board, and Conformity Assessment Board, as well as a variety of technical committees and working groups.

nodes.name: ISO/IEC JTC 1
nodes.data: ISO/IEC JTC1 was formed as a merger of three subcommittees to avoid duplicative or incompatible standards between standards bodies. The group's purpose is to develop, maintain, and promote standards in the fields of information technology and information and communications technology. JTC1 subcommittees and working groups are responsible for more than 2600 published standards in areas such as programming languages, character sets, and multimedia. The secretariat of JTC1 is ANSI.

nodes.name: Internet Society
nodes.data: The Internet Society (abbreviated ISoc) is an international non-profit organization founded by Vint Cerf and Robert Kahn to provide leadership in Internet-related standards, education, and public policy. ISoc has more than 65,000 individual members, 145 member organizations, and 100 regional chapters governed by a Board of Trustees. It is the parent organization of the IETF and holds the copyright to all IETF standards documents. It is also the parent organization of the IAB, the IESG, and the IRTF.

nodes.name: IETF
nodes.data: The Internet Engineering Task Force was founded in 1986 with a mission to “to make the Internet work better“ and thus focuses on developing voluntary standards for TCP/IP. There is no formal membership or membership requirements to IETF, though contributorship statistics are available. IETF was a US Government-sponsored activity until 1993, when it was transferred to the Internet Society to provide corporate structure. IESG is responsible for the operation of IETF, and the IAB oversees its external relationships.

nodes.name: IESG
nodes.data: The Internet Engineering Steering Group is responsible for technical management of IETF activities and for overseeing the Internet standards process. It is comprised of the IETF Chairperson and a group of IETF Area Directors who are selected by a Nominations Committee. IESG members serve a term of two years.

nodes.name: IAB
nodes.data: The Internet Architecture Board is an Internet Society committee charged with technical and engineering development of the Internet through oversight of the IETF and IRTF. Originally formed in 1979 as the Internet Configuration Control Board, it became the Internet Advisory Board in 1984 and later the Internet Activities Board in 1986. The modern form of the IAB was created in 1992 when the Internet Protocol was transferred from a government entity to ISoc. IAB is comprised of 13 members - the IETF chairperson and 12 appointed members.

nodes.name: IRTF
nodes.data: The Internet Research Task Force is an IAB committee responsible for long term research issues related to the Internet. It is comprised of 9 different research groups in areas such as cryptography, Internet congestion control, global access, and software-defined networking. IRTF is managed by the IRTF chairperson and the IRSG, a 27-person steering committee.

nodes.name: TC39
nodes.data: Technical Committee 39 works on standardization of the ECMAScript language for the standards body Ecma International. The group is comprised of 20-30 individuals from Ecma member organizations and meets bi-monthly. It is responsible for the latest version of ECMAScript as specified in ECMA-262 and its companion test suite, as well as current work on ECMAScript 6, also called Harmony or ES.next. The TC39-Royalty Free Task Group was created to allow non-Ecma members to contribute to the specification.

nodes.name: RICG
nodes.data: The Responsive Images Community Group is a group of developers working on “a client-side solution for delivering alternate image data based on device capabilities to prevent wasted bandwidth and optimize display for both screen and print.“ It is a W3C Community Group created by Mat Marquis in 2012 in response to a disagreement with WHATWG. To its creators' knowledge, it is the only community group to have their implementation accepted into both the W3C and WHATWG HTML specifications.

nodes.name: W3C TAG
nodes.data: The W3C Technical Architecture Group is chartered by the W3C’s Process Document with stewardship of the overall architecture of the Web. The group coordinates developments across varying web technologies and working groups to help resolve issues and provide direction as necessary. W3C Founder Tim Berners-Lee serves as the chair of the 9-person group, which includes 5 members elected from by the W3C Advisory Committee and 3 members appointed by the chair.

nodes.name: CSS Working Group
nodes.data: The CSS Working Group writes and maintains drafts and specifications for CSS and its varying modules. The group is open to public participation via its mailing list and blog, however official CSS Working Group membership is limited to individuals in W3C member organizations. Its W3C charter expired in September 2013, however the group remains in operation.

nodes.name: HTML Working Group
nodes.data: The HTML Working Group was chartered by the W3C to “define and continue the development of HTML and the APIs for interacting with its resources.“ The group is open to public participation via email and irc; however to officially join the group one must belong to a W3C member organization and receive nomination from an Advisory Committee representative, or get special approval of the group’s Chairs. Its charter expires in June 2015.

nodes.name: SVG Working Group
nodes.data: The SVG Working Group is chartered by the W3C to “continue the evolution of Scalable Vector Graphics as a format and a platform, and enhance the adoption and usability of SVG.” Most notably, the group works on syntax, styling, and an API for SVG. While the SVG Working Group’s proceedings are public via a mailing list and weekly teleconference, there are no clear directions for officially joining SVG Working Group membership. The group’s charter expires in October 2016.

nodes.name: Math Working Group
nodes.data: The Math Working Group was formed to “facilitate and promote the use of the Web for mathematical and scientific communication.” Its primary deliverable is MathML 3.0, which was published as a W3C recommendation on April 10, 2014, and a corresponding test suite. Official participation in the group follows rules outlined in Section 6.2.1 of the W3C Process Document, but group discussions are available for public comment via a mailing list. The Math Working Group’s charter expires in March 2016.

nodes.name: Web Applications Working Group
nodes.data: Formerly the WebAPI and Web Application Format Working Groups, the W3C’s Web Applications Working Group was formed to “provide specifications that enable improved client-side application development on the Web.” The group works on an array of technologies which can extend existing specifications in other working groups, including Web Components, Web Workers, and DOM events to name a few. Public discussion is available on the group’s mailing list, though official membership is restricted to those following Section 6.2.1 of the W3C Process Document. The group’s charter expires in July 2016.
